channel.name: Unable To Transfer Custom Token From Account A to Account B using Account C

messages.content: (NOTE: I simplified the code slightly. In the real version, the "funderAddress" is derived from the combination of a public key and a Field, in the method of the zkApp)

You are trying to allow sending of tokens without signature. For this to work you need:
1. set the permission of send to none
2. make sure it will be properly authorised using token owner account

It might seem counter-intuitive that we are not setting the authorisation permission to proof, however keep in mind that proof is being verified against the verification key in the corresponding account. In your case that would be token account of `interactor2PrivateKey` (which has no verification key) and not the verification key of the smart contract. It is okay that the permission will be none, since for the token account update to succeed, it needs to be approved by the token owner account. 

For this you might need to create account updates manually. You need to create sender and receiver account updates with no authorisation and approve both of them.
Hello, and tahnk you very much for your answer! I will write a detailed reply soon.

Hello, coming with further answers:

> 1.set the permission of send to none
The permission of send is already set to Permissions.none(). The relevant code is included in the messages above.

> For this you might need to create account updates manually. You need to create sender and receiver account updates with no authorisation and approve both of them. 

Isn't this what I'm already doing for the sender in `sendFromTo()`? How would I create an account update for the receiver?

I'm currently studying the Wrapped Token examples from https://github.com/o1-labs/docs2/tree/main/examples/zkapps/11-advanced-account-updates and have re-read all of the updated documentation on tokens, but things are still not the clearest.

Thank you.

messages.content:
> The permission of send is already set to Permissions.none(). The relevant code is included in the messages above.
You are setting the permission of token owner account. Beware that's not a good idea, if there would be any funds in the smart contract anybody could withdraw that.

What you want to do instead, set the permission of the user's token account when it's created.

> Isn't this what I'm already doing for the sender in sendFromTo()? How would I create an account update for the receiver?
This sets the authorisation to the signature, which you are trying to avoid.

Maybe this example that sets authorizations to token accounts can be of little help:
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/src/contract/names.ts#L164
@DFST Thank you, will check it our right now!
So do essentially I set the permissions on the account before transfering for the first time?

In my understanding yes, you should set the permissions on the token account when you are creating it. Additionally, you can set the verification key to the token account to implement any additional logic that is required for transfer or any other operation, see for example
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/experimental/payment.v2.test.ts#L289

In this example I do not transfer the token to other account, instead I change the owner PublicKey field in the token account that allows to control the token account, but the same technique can be used probably with token transfers to other accounts.
@DFST a HUGE MASSIVE thank you on this! Going to refactor in that direction now. I will write with updates

Yes, exactly.
It is https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/experimental/payment.v2.test.ts#L195 in second
and more complicated rollup example:

Thank you, I see now! The problem is that in my case `<pub_key>` is a derived public key. The tokens in the possession of that `<pub_key>` should not be usable by the owner of the corresponding private key. The balances in `<pub_key>` are to be managed by the smart contract that defines the token (extends TokenContract).

I know you're also hacking around with balances for storage. In my case it's similar, but the private key cannot be used to control those funds.

It's not a problem as the token accounts cannot be managed without main SmartContract that creates the token, so you can put any logic there - see for example KYC logic in my example.
You cannot editState of the token account directly - only thru main contract.

Well, this random account should have MINA, otherwise the tx will fail, and this transaction should be signed by private key.

Do you mean actually transferring your token and not MINA?
Yes, my token

Then you can create the token account for every user, the user should have private key for creation of the account, and the balance of the user should be written in some UInt64 field on the token account.
The main contract then will manage this field by decreasing or increasing it - in this way the private key of the user cannot made transfers without following main contract logic and mainly used to confirm sender identity by using `this.sender.getAndRequireSignature()`
It is not a standard way to do it, so I'm not sure that it is a best way - maybe it makes sense to return to your original idea and make transfers of the tokens setting authorizations right and approveBase()

Actually..... I think I could just deploy a new smart contract for each one of those `<public_key>`s, and use them for balance storage like you described. This could actually simplify things a lot! I would still only need to pay 1 account creation fee (for the deployment of the smart contract, instead of creation of a new token accout). These are some great ideas, thank you!

I'm still wondering if I wanted to do initially is possible (not a quetion to you, but anyone reading after)

You are going to pay 1 MINA fee anyways to create token account. When making decision token accounts vs usual accounts you should also take into account how you will upgrade the contract in the future. With token accounts, it is one tx, with usual accounts - ${number_of_users} txs

The upgrade point is a very valid one, but I don't think it will be necessary on those accounts.

The question that I'm exploring now, is how to obtain the address of the deployer of a smart contract, or at least how to achieve the equivalent of checking whether a smart contract was deployed via another smart contract; or rahter for a smart contract A to verify whether the smart contract B that it's interacting with  it has been deployed by the smart contract A.
I don't think it is possible in general, the only possibility is to put some flag into the B's state.
Do you know any way of ensuring that that flag was indeed set by Smart Contract A, without having access to Smart Contract A's key?

Yes, you can keep MerkleTree/Map root on the A state, and put into this Tree/Map { flag (number) : B PublicKey hash or PublicKey.x}. Although updating this Map/Tree is difficult. 
In case of token accounts, it is automatic - there is 100% guarantee that the contract is deployed by A
Thanks. The reason I went with this "token hack" is to avoid using off-chain storage. Looks like the solution is still not quite there, but I'm sure that it's coming!
You can use events and actions also for off-chain storage

Given what you're trying to achieve, I see only 3 variants for now:
1) Use token accounts. You will need private key once to create this account. Then, this private key will not be able to control the funds. This private key can be a) the private key of A account b) Temporarily private key being discarded after token account creation, with public key of A different from public key of token account
2) Use actions storage. You can see examples
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1475
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1300
Be aware of 
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1426
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1427
3) Classic case with storing MerkleMap root on-chain and keeping the data off-chain, for example in IPFS or in Events.
What keeps anyone from deploying smart contract B outside of your method with custom verification key?
For this to work how you want, it needs to be a token account of smart contract A
